node.title: Two 'boozy parties' at Downing St night before Queen sat alone to farewell Prince Philip
node.description: As the Queen prepared for one of her hardest days, staff at Downing St partied.
node.content: ["There were two \"boozy parties\" at 10 Downing St the night before the funeral of Prince Philip, the\u00a0Telegraph is reporting.", "The incredible revelation comes off the back of a series of reports over the last two months alleging parties were held at the residence and workplace of the British Prime Minister and at a number of other UK government departments throughout pandemic lockdowns.", "Boris Johnson on Thursday apologised for attending a party at Downing St on May 20, 2020 while COVID-19 measures were in place. He, however, said the event was an office gathering, technically allowed under the rules.", "But the Telegraph now reports that two parties were also held on April 16, the day before Prince Philip, the Queen's husband, was laid to rest at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.", "In farewelling her life partner, the Queen sat alone, respecting the COVID-19 rules in place.\u00a0 Images of her alone on what would have been one of her most difficult days quickly went viral, with people sending their thoughts and sympathy to the monarch.", "It's alleged that one of the parties saw staff party in the building's basement until the early hours of next morning and that someone broke a swing of Wilfred Johnson's, the Prime Minister's son.\u00a0", "Regarding one of the parties, a Downing St spokesperson said: \"On this individual\u2019s last day he gave a farewell speech to thank each team for the work they had done to support him, both those who had to be in the office for work and on a screen for those working from home.\"", "At the time, indoor gatherings were banned and only six people could be together outdoors.\u00a0", "Johnson himself was not at Downing St on that date, a spokesperson said.", "An investigation is already underway into the gatherings, while both some of Johnson's own MPs and Opposition politicians are calling for his resignation.", "More to come."]
